question: Question_01_(i)
sols:
Use integration by parts with

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
u = x \quad\text{and}\quad dv = e^{2x}\end{align*} we obtain:

\begin{align*}
\int xe^{2x}\,dx &= \frac{xe^{2x}}{2} - \int \frac{1}{2}e^{2x}\,dx \\
&= \frac{xe^{2x}}{2} - \frac{1}{4}e^{2x} + C \\
&= \frac{(2x - 1)e^{2x}}{4} + C\end{align*}

where $C$ is a constant.
hints:
What technique of integration does one generally use when integrating a
product of functions?

What makes computing the integral

\begin{align*}\int xe^{x^2}\,dx\end{align*} very different?
